Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant is a Convention refugee under the Immigration Act
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Bouianova was born in Russia but lived in Latvia; claimed statelessness and persecution in Latvia; had access to Russian citizenship through a simple passport stamping process
Decision_Outcome: Applicant is not a Convention refugee
Remedy_Requested: Recognition as a Convention refugee and grant of refugee status in Canada
Legal_Standard: Unable or unwilling to return due to fear
Assessment_Factor: Lack of evidence of persecution in Russia
Applicable_Legislation: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court reviewing Refugee Board's decision
Credibility_Assessment: No explicit credibility issues raised; claim rejected based on legal interpretation and factual findings
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding Bouianova's eligibility for Russian citizenship
Documentation of her residence in Latvia
Lack of evidence showing persecution in Russia
Legal_Provision_Cited: Definition of Convention refugee under the Immigration Act
Application_Basis: Claim of statelessness and fear of persecution
Evidence_Assessed: Proof of ability to obtain Russian citizenship
Absence of evidence of persecution in Russia
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee status in Canada
Governing_Rule: A Convention refugee must have a well-founded fear of persecution and be outside their country of nationality, unable or unwilling to return
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of persecution in Russia
Failure to demonstrate inability to access Russian citizenship
Harm_Assessment: No harm established due to availability of protection in Russia
Cause_Description: Bouianova claimed refugee status in Canada due to statelessness and alleged persecution in Latvia
Evidence_Handling: Court assessed documentary and testimonial evidence regarding citizenship eligibility and conditions in Russia
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient evidence to support claim of persecution
Clear evidence that Russian citizenship was accessible
Residency_Compliance: Applicant resided in Latvia but retained ties to Russia
Legal_Provision: Section defining Convention refugee in the Immigration Act
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the Refugee Board had jurisdiction over a person entitled to Russian citizenship
Evidence_Assessment: The court found that the applicant did not meet the burden of proof for refugee status
Decision_Rationale: Applicant is entitled to Russian citizenship and there is no evidence of persecution in Russia; therefore, she does not meet the definition of a Convention refugee
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of credible evidence supporting persecution
Demonstrated availability of state protection via Russian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Refugee Convention
